title: 107_hr3223
content: The Act may be cited as the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purposes are outlined. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation. Service connections will be included for facilities in Dulce and surrounding areas. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to enter into a self-determination contract with the Jicarilla Apache Nation for planning, designing, and constructing water supply and wastewater systems. The Bureau of Reclamation will provide technical assistance and oversight for the project. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the water system as part of the project authorized by the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act." SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include the terms "Act" referring to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act, "BIA" for the Bureau of Indian Affairs, "irrigation" for water application in commercial agriculture, "Reclamation" for the Bureau of Reclamation, and "Report" for a specific planning report completed in 2001. The term "Reservation" refers to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico, including lands held in trust by the United States for the Tribe. The term "Rural Water Supply Project" pertains to water supply and wastewater facilities serving towns, communities, tribal reservations, and farmsteads in New Mexico. The term "State" specifically denotes the State of New Mexico. The term "State" refers to the State of New Mexico, while the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" specifically denotes the Jicarilla Apache Nation. SEC. 4. JICARILLA APACHE RESERVATION RURAL WATER SYSTEM. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will construct the Rural Water Supply Project to improve water supply and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services for Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation. Pumping and treatment facilities will be located on the Reservation, along with distribution, collection, and treatment facilities to serve the Reservation's needs. The curr_chunk discusses the construction, replacement, improvement, and repair of water and wastewater systems on the Reservation, including necessary property, electrical power facilities, and other infrastructure deemed necessary by the Secretary. Cost sharing is also mentioned. The curr_chunk discusses the tribal and federal cost sharing for the Rural Water Supply Project, including design, construction, and maintenance of various water facilities on the Reservation. The Federal share of the cost of operation and maintenance of the Rural Water Supply Project shall be covered by the Tribe after completion, as per the Operation, Maintenance, and Replacement Plan outlined in the Report. The Secretary has the authority to enter agreements and regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project, including maps and engineering drawings. The Tribe will develop an OM&R plan for operation and maintenance. A construction manager will be selected to assist with the project. The Secretary will work with the Tribe to select a construction manager for the Rural Water Supply Project. A memorandum of agreement will be signed to address operations and maintenance during and after construction. The Secretary will provide oversight and technical assistance to the Tribe for planning and development of the project. The Rural Water Supply Project will provide technical assistance to the Tribe for planning, development, and construction within the Reservation boundaries. The project will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act, and the Secretary will report to Congress on its progress. Title to the project will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States. Title to the Rural Water Supply Project will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States and cannot be transferred without an Act of Congress. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of $45,000,000 for the Rural Water Supply Project planning, design, and construction, subject to completion of appraisal investigation, feasibility study, and NEPA requirements. The Secretary must meet NEPA requirements before obligating funds for construction of the Rural Water Supply Project. SEC. 8. PROHIBITION ON USE OF FUNDS FOR IRRIGATION PURPOSES. None of the funds for the Rural Water Supply Project can be used for irrigation facilities. SEC. 9. WATER RIGHTS. The water rights of the Jicarilla Apache Tribe are included in the Water Rights Settlement Act and adjudicated under New Mexico State law. These rights provide water for the municipal water system without impacting other tribal water rights. The Rural Water Supply Project will not result in new water depletions and has been determined to have no significant impact on endangered species.
